speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: SCENE III. The lists at Coventry.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Enter the Lord Marshal and the DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: My Lord Aumerle, is Harry Hereford arm'd?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Yea, at all points; and longs to enter in.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: The Duke of Norfolk, sprightfully and bold,

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Stays but the summons of the appellant's trumpet.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Why, then, the champions are prepared, and stay

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: For nothing but his majesty's approach.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: The trumpets sound, and KING RICHARD enters with  his nobles, JOHN OF GAUNT, BUSHY, BAGOT, GREEN, and  others. When they are set, enter THOMAS MOWBRAY in arms, defendant, with a Herald

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Marshal, demand of yonder champion

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The cause of his arrival here in arms:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ask him his name and orderly proceed

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To swear him in the justice of his cause.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: In God's name and the king's, say who thou art

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: And why thou comest thus knightly clad in arms,

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Against what man thou comest, and what thy quarrel:

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Speak truly, on thy knighthood and thy oath;

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: As so defend thee heaven and thy valour!

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: My name is Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Who hither come engaged by my oath--

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which God defend a knight should violate!--

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Both to defend my loyalty and truth

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: To God, my king and my succeeding issue,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Against the Duke of Hereford that appeals me

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And, by the grace of God and this mine arm,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: To prove him, in defending of myself,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A traitor to my God, my king, and me:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The trumpets sound. Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE, appellant, in armour, with a Herald

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Marshal, ask yonder knight in arms,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Both who he is and why he cometh hither

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thus plated in habiliments of war,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And formally, according to our law,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Depose him in the justice of his cause.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: What is thy name? and wherefore comest thou hither,

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Before King Richard in his royal lists?

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Against whom comest thou? and what's thy quarrel?

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Speak like a true knight, so defend thee heaven!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Am I; who ready here do stand in arms,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To prove, by God's grace and my body's valour,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: In lists, on Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That he is a traitor, foul and dangerous,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To God of heaven, King Richard and to me;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: On pain of death, no person be so bold

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Or daring-hardy as to touch the lists,

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Except the marshal and such officers

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Appointed to direct these fair designs.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Lord marshal, let me kiss my sovereign's hand,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And bow my knee before his majesty:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: For Mowbray and myself are like two men

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That vow a long and weary pilgrimage;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Then let us take a ceremonious leave

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And loving farewell of our several friends.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: The appellant in all duty greets your highness,

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: And craves to kiss your hand and take his leave.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We will descend and fold him in our arms.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cousin of Hereford, as thy cause is right,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So be thy fortune in this royal fight!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Farewell, my blood; which if to-day thou shed,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Lament we may, but not revenge thee dead.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O let no noble eye profane a tear

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: For me, if I be gored with Mowbray's spear:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As confident as is the falcon's flight

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Against a bird, do I with Mowbray fight.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My loving lord, I take my leave of you;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of you, my noble cousin, Lord Aumerle;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Not sick, although I have to do with death,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But lusty, young, and cheerly drawing breath.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Lo, as at English feasts, so I regreet

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The daintiest last, to make the end most sweet:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O thou, the earthly author of my blood,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Whose youthful spirit, in me regenerate,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Doth with a twofold vigour lift me up

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To reach at victory above my head,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Add proof unto mine armour with thy prayers;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And with thy blessings steel my lance's point,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That it may enter Mowbray's waxen coat,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And furbish new the name of John a Gaunt,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Even in the lusty havior of his son.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: God in thy good cause make thee prosperous!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Be swift like lightning in the execution;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And let thy blows, doubly redoubled,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Fall like amazing thunder on the casque

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Of thy adverse pernicious enemy:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Rouse up thy youthful blood, be valiant and live.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Mine innocency and Saint George to thrive!

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: However God or fortune cast my lot,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: There lives or dies, true to King Richard's throne,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A loyal, just and upright gentleman:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Never did captive with a freer heart

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Cast off his chains of bondage and embrace

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: His golden uncontroll'd enfranchisement,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: More than my dancing soul doth celebrate

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: This feast of battle with mine adversary.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Most mighty liege, and my companion peers,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Take from my mouth the wish of happy years:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: As gentle and as jocund as to jest

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Go I to fight: truth hath a quiet breast.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Farewell, my lord: securely I espy

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Virtue with valour couched in thine eye.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Order the trial, marshal, and begin.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby,

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Receive thy lance; and God defend the right!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Strong as a tower in hope, I cry amen.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Go bear this lance to Thomas, Duke of Norfolk.

speaker: First Herald
text_entry: Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby,

speaker: First Herald
text_entry: Stands here for God, his sovereign and himself,

speaker: First Herald
text_entry: On pain to be found false and recreant,

speaker: First Herald
text_entry: To prove the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray,

speaker: First Herald
text_entry: A traitor to his God, his king and him;

speaker: First Herald
text_entry: And dares him to set forward to the fight.

speaker: Second Herald
text_entry: Here standeth Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk,

speaker: Second Herald
text_entry: On pain to be found false and recreant,

speaker: Second Herald
text_entry: Both to defend himself and to approve

speaker: Second Herald
text_entry: Henry of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby,

speaker: Second Herald
text_entry: To God, his sovereign and to him disloyal;

speaker: Second Herald
text_entry: Courageously and with a free desire

speaker: Second Herald
text_entry: Attending but the signal to begin.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Sound, trumpets; and set forward, combatants.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: A charge sounded

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: Stay, the king hath thrown his warder down.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let them lay by their helmets and their spears,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And both return back to their chairs again:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Withdraw with us: and let the trumpets sound

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: While we return these dukes what we decree.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A long flourish

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Draw near,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And list what with our council we have done.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For that our kingdom's earth should not be soil'd

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With that dear blood which it hath fostered;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And for our eyes do hate the dire aspect

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Of civil wounds plough'd up with neighbours' sword;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And for we think the eagle-winged pride

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Of sky-aspiring and ambitious thoughts,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With rival-hating envy, set on you

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To wake our peace, which in our country's cradle

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Draws the sweet infant breath of gentle sleep;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which so roused up with boisterous untuned drums,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With harsh resounding trumpets' dreadful bray,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And grating shock of wrathful iron arms,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Might from our quiet confines fright fair peace

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And make us wade even in our kindred's blood,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Therefore, we banish you our territories:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: You, cousin Hereford, upon pain of life,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Till twice five summers have enrich'd our fields

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall not regreet our fair dominions,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But tread the stranger paths of banishment.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Your will be done: this must my comfort be,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Sun that warms you here shall shine on me;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And those his golden beams to you here lent

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Shall point on me and gild my banishment.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Norfolk, for thee remains a heavier doom,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which I with some unwillingness pronounce:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The sly slow hours shall not determinate

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The dateless limit of thy dear exile;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The hopeless word of 'never to return'

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Breathe I against thee, upon pain of life.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A heavy sentence, my most sovereign liege,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And all unlook'd for from your highness' mouth:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A dearer merit, not so deep a maim

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: As to be cast forth in the common air,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Have I deserved at your highness' hands.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The language I have learn'd these forty years,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: My native English, now I must forego:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And now my tongue's use is to me no more

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Than an unstringed viol or a harp,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Or like a cunning instrument cased up,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Or, being open, put into his hands

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: That knows no touch to tune the harmony:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Doubly portcullis'd with my teeth and lips;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And dull unfeeling barren ignorance

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Is made my gaoler to attend on me.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I am too old to fawn upon a nurse,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Too far in years to be a pupil now:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: What is thy sentence then but speechless death,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which robs my tongue from breathing native breath?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: It boots thee not to be compassionate:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: After our sentence plaining comes too late.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Then thus I turn me from my country's light,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: To dwell in solemn shades of endless night.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Return again, and take an oath with thee.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Lay on our royal sword your banish'd hands;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Swear by the duty that you owe to God--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our part therein we banish with yourselves--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To keep the oath that we administer:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: You never shall, so help you truth and God!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Embrace each other's love in banishment;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor never look upon each other's face;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor never write, regreet, nor reconcile

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This louring tempest of your home-bred hate;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor never by advised purpose meet

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To plot, contrive, or complot any ill

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: 'Gainst us, our state, our subjects, or our land.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I swear.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And I, to keep all this.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Norfolk, so far as to mine enemy:--

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By this time, had the king permitted us,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: One of our souls had wander'd in the air.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Banish'd this frail sepulchre of our flesh,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As now our flesh is banish'd from this land:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Confess thy treasons ere thou fly the realm;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Since thou hast far to go, bear not along

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The clogging burthen of a guilty soul.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: No, Bolingbroke: if ever I were traitor,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: My name be blotted from the book of life,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And I from heaven banish'd as from hence!

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: But what thou art, God, thou, and I do know;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And all too soon, I fear, the king shall rue.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Farewell, my liege. Now no way can I stray;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Save back to England, all the world's my way.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Uncle, even in the glasses of thine eyes

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I see thy grieved heart: thy sad aspect

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Hath from the number of his banish'd years

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Pluck'd four away.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To HENRY BOLINGBROKE

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Six frozen winter spent,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Return with welcome home from banishment.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: How long a time lies in one little word!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Four lagging winters and four wanton springs

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: End in a word: such is the breath of kings.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: I thank my liege, that in regard of me

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: He shortens four years of my son's exile:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But little vantage shall I reap thereby;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For, ere the six years that he hath to spend

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Can change their moons and bring their times about

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted light

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Shall be extinct with age and endless night;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: My inch of taper will be burnt and done,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And blindfold death not let me see my son.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Why uncle, thou hast many years to live.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But not a minute, king, that thou canst give:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Shorten my days thou canst with sullen sorrow,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And pluck nights from me, but not lend a morrow;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Thou canst help time to furrow me with age,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But stop no wrinkle in his pilgrimage;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Thy word is current with him for my death,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But dead, thy kingdom cannot buy my breath.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thy son is banish'd upon good advice,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whereto thy tongue a party-verdict gave:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Why at our justice seem'st thou then to lour?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Things sweet to taste prove in digestion sour.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: You urged me as a judge; but I had rather

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: You would have bid me argue like a father.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, had it been a stranger, not my child,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To smooth his fault I should have been more mild:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: A partial slander sought I to avoid,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And in the sentence my own life destroy'd.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Alas, I look'd when some of you should say,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: I was too strict to make mine own away;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But you gave leave to my unwilling tongue

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Against my will to do myself this wrong.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cousin, farewell; and, uncle, bid him so:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Six years we banish him, and he shall go.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt KING RICHARD II and train

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Cousin, farewell: what presence must not know,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: From where you do remain let paper show.

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: My lord, no leave take I; for I will ride,

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: As far as land will let me, by your side.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, to what purpose dost thou hoard thy words,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: That thou return'st no greeting to thy friends?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I have too few to take my leave of you,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: When the tongue's office should be prodigal

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Thy grief is but thy absence for a time.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Joy absent, grief is present for that time.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: What is six winters? they are quickly gone.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To men in joy; but grief makes one hour ten.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Call it a travel that thou takest for pleasure.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My heart will sigh when I miscall it so,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which finds it an inforced pilgrimage.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The sullen passage of thy weary steps

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Esteem as foil wherein thou art to set

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The precious jewel of thy home return.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Nay, rather, every tedious stride I make

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Will but remember me what a deal of world

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I wander from the jewels that I love.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Must I not serve a long apprenticehood

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To foreign passages, and in the end,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Having my freedom, boast of nothing else

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But that I was a journeyman to grief?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: All places that the eye of heaven visits

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Are to a wise man ports and happy havens.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Teach thy necessity to reason thus;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: There is no virtue like necessity.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Think not the king did banish thee,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But thou the king. Woe doth the heavier sit,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Where it perceives it is but faintly borne.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Go, say I sent thee forth to purchase honour

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And not the king exiled thee; or suppose

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Devouring pestilence hangs in our air

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And thou art flying to a fresher clime:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Look, what thy soul holds dear, imagine it

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To lie that way thou go'st, not whence thou comest:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Suppose the singing birds musicians,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The grass whereon thou tread'st the presence strew'd,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The flowers fair ladies, and thy steps no more

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Than a delightful measure or a dance;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The man that mocks at it and sets it light.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O, who can hold a fire in his hand

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By thinking on the frosty Caucasus?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By bare imagination of a feast?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or wallow naked in December snow

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By thinking on fantastic summer's heat?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O, no! the apprehension of the good

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Gives but the greater feeling to the worse:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Than when he bites, but lanceth not the sore.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Come, come, my son, I'll bring thee on thy way:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Had I thy youth and cause, I would not stay.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Then, England's ground, farewell; sweet soil, adieu;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Where'er I wander, boast of this I can,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Though banish'd, yet a trueborn Englishman.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt
